comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Knew that'd say "No dogs" before the power vested in me by Google Translate allowed the Chinese > English translation!  :D
Early regulations regarding rabies and a particularly virulent form of canine distemper precluded the transportation of dogs between Scotland and Ireland at this time, and that's why there're no dogs in this photo. Honest!

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content:
Found some info. on The Lizard 1176 gross tons built by The Clyde Shipping Co. and launched in 1895.Sold to Turkey in 1925 and renamed Chanak-Kaleh.Scrapped in 1959.
Whats the flowers in most of the lapels? wedding party,paddys day?.My monitors too crappy to see it well.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] You did indeed. Excellent info. There seems to be a range of foliage. I thought that the captain had shamrock, but the others seem to have other varieties, including white heather (for luck?) in the button hole of a nervous traveller. I've put a note...

On the grounds that the Lizard doesn't look absolutely brand spanking new, and you say it was launched in 1895, I'm starting the bidding at 1896.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content:
The Lizard? Kind of a weird name for a ship.

They all look like they're dressed in period costumes from "Anne of Green Gables" (Canadian story), which takes place at about this time period.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: mariners-list.com/site_pages.php?section=Shipping+Compani... that's another link for the Lizard ship info. or this pdf, describes the ship in detail (scroll down to the Lizard): www.fdca.org.uk/pdf files/Caledon L.pdf Single Screw Steel Steamship, built in Glasgow. sold in 1924 to Turkey. Seems the area was under French control following the Ottoman defeat in WW1.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content:
I imagine it was named for The Lizard point in Cornwall.

Çanakkale is a seaport in Turkey, but alas, no relation to dogs found there. Was the site of the Battle of Galipoli in WW1, a few years after this photo was taken.

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Facial hair seems to be falling out of favour with the younger set in this group.

comment.author: 59941010@N06
comment._content: Another great image.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
Other notes on the Lizard:
* Ship name: Lizard
* Original owner: Clyde Shipping Co., Glasgow
* Home port: Glasgow
* Yard number: 128
* Launched: 1895
* Type: Single Screw Steel Steamship
* Contract number: 104647
* History:
** 1924 - Renamed "Altoun Tash". New owner "Administration de Navires Turque". Home port becomes Istanbul.
** Later - Renamed "Chanka-Kale". Same owners. Same port
** Later - Renamed "Canakkale". New owner "Denseilil Bankasi T.A." Same port
** Later - Transfered to "Denzizyollari Ideise".  Same port
** 1959 -  Scrapped at Istanbul

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] And she don't look one bit pleased either!  Has a rather glum look on her probably because her hubby has his arm on her shoulder showing his ownership while the captain tries to catch her attention.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Just picked up this tidbit www.flickr.com/photos/scottishmaritimemuseum/4901413302/: Clyde Shipping Company’s coasting trade was developed between Scotland and Ireland, and this was reflected in its original houseflag, shown here. It is a double pennant with the Scottish lion and Irish harp as emblems. As the trade with England developed, and Ireland was partitioned, this flag was no longer seen as appropriate. It was replaced in 1924 with a single blue pennant with a lighthouse and the letters CSC, which offended no national susceptibilities and reflected the fact that the company’s vessels were named after lighthouses and lightships.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Clyde Shipping Company tended to name their ships after lighthouses. When they took over the Waterford Steamship Company, they renamed the SS Clodagh as the Coningbeg, and the Dunbrody was renamed the Arklow.
